cellularAutomata.rules.templates
Class RealVectorRuleTemplate

java.lang.Object
  cellularAutomata.rules.RuleActions
      cellularAutomata.rules.Rule
          cellularAutomata.rules.templates.RealVectorRuleTemplate
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.event.ActionListener, java.beans.PropertyChangeListener, java.util.EventListener
Direct Known Subclasses:
ExampleVectorAverage
public abstract class RealVectorRuleTemplate
extends Rule

A convenience class/template for any rules that need cell states based on a double array of values. (In other words, this class uses the cell state cellularAutomaton.cellState.model.RealValuedVectorState.)

This class uses the Template Method design pattern. Subclasses implement the abstract methods doubleVectorRule(), getMaximumPermissableValue(), and getMaximumPermissableValue() which are called by the template method calculateNewState().

Author:
David Bahr

Constructor Detail

RealVectorRuleTemplate

public RealVectorRuleTemplate(boolean minimalOrLazyInitialization)
Create a rule based on a double array of values.

When building child classes, the minimalOrLazyInitialization parameter must be included but may be ignored. However, the boolean is intended to indicate when the child's constructor should build a rule with as small a footprint as possible. In order to load rules by reflection, the application must query the child classes for information like their display names, tooltip descriptions, etc. At these times it makes no sense to build the complete rule which may have a large footprint in memory.

It is recommended that the child's constructor and instance variables do not initialize any variables and that variables be initialized only when first needed (lazy initialization). Or all initializations in the constructor may be placed in an if statement. 

 if(!minimalOrLazyInitialization)
 {
     ...initialize
 }

Parameters:
minimalOrLazyInitialization - When true, the constructor instantiates an object with as small a footprint as possible. When false, the rule is fully constructed. If uncertain, set this variable to false.
Method Detail

calculateNewState

public CellState calculateNewState(Cell cell,
                                   Cell[] neighbors)
Creates a new RealValuedVectorState based on an array provided by the method doubleVectorRule().
By convention the neighbors should be indexed clockwise starting to the northwest of the cell.

Specified by:
calculateNewState in class Rule
Parameters:
cell - The cell being updated.
neighbors - The cells on which the update is based (usually neighboring cells). By convention the neighbors should be indexed clockwise starting to the northwest of the cell. May be null if want this method to find the "neighboring" cells.
Returns:
A new state for the cell.
See Also:
Rule.calculateNewState(cellularAutomata.Cell, cellularAutomata.Cell[])

getCompatibleCellState

public final CellState getCompatibleCellState()
Description copied from class: Rule
Gets an instance of the CellState class that is compatible with this rule (must be the same as the type returned by the method calculateNewState()). The values assigned to this instance (via its constructor) will be used by all the CellStates -- this is the proper way to set static instance variables in the CellState class. Appropriate CellStates to return include BinaryCellState, IntegerCellState, IntegerVectorState, and RealValuedVectorState among others.

This method must return a different cellState instance every time it is called. If not, will print a warning, and all the cells may hold the exact same state. For example, the following would be appropriate "return new IntegerCellState(2, 0, view);" where "view" is a CellStateView.

Specified by:
getCompatibleCellState in class Rule
Returns:
An instance of the CellState (any values passed to the constructor of the CellState should match those values needed by this rule).
See Also:
Rule.getCompatibleCellState()

getCompatibleCellStateView

public CellStateView getCompatibleCellStateView()
Gets an instance of the CellStateView class that will be used to display cells being updated by this rule. Note: This method must return a view that is able to display cell states of the type returned by the method getCompatibleCellState(). Appropriate CellStatesViews to return include BinaryCellStateView, IntegerCellStateView, HexagonalIntegerCellStateView, IntegerVectorArrowView, IntegerVectorDefaultView, and RealValuedDefaultView among others. the user may also create their own views (see online documentation).

Any values passed to the constructor of the CellStateView should match those values needed by this rule.

Specified by:
getCompatibleCellStateView in class Rule
Returns:
An instance of the CellStateView (any values passed to the constructor of the CellStateView should match those values needed by this rule).

getCompatibleLattices

public java.lang.String[] getCompatibleLattices()
A list of lattices with which this Rule will work; in this case, returns all lattices by default, though child classes may wish to override this and restrict the lattices with which the child rule will work.
Well-designed Rules should work with any lattice, but some may require particular topological or geometrical information (like the lattice gas). Appropriate strings to return in the array include SquareLattice.DISPLAY_NAME, HexagonalLattice.DISPLAY_NAME, StandardOneDimensionalLattice.DISPLAY_NAME, etc. If null, will be compatible with all lattices.

Specified by:
getCompatibleLattices in class Rule
Returns:
A list of lattices compatible with this Rule (returns the display names for the lattices). Returns null if compatible with all lattices.

getMaximumPermissibleValue

public abstract double getMaximumPermissibleValue()
Gets the maximum permissible value for each element of the vector. Do not recommend using Double.MAX_VALUE unless your code very carefully checks for instances of Infinity.
This method is used by the AbstractRealVectorRule class to properly construct a RealValuedVectorState.

Returns:
The maximum permissible value.

getMinimumPermissibleValue

public abstract double getMinimumPermissibleValue()
Gets the minimum permissible value for each element of the vector. Do not recommend using Double.MIN_VALUE unless your code very carefully checks for instances of Infinity.
This method is used by the AbstractRealVectorRule class to properly construct a RealValuedVectorState.

Returns:
The minimum permissible value.

getVectorLength

public abstract int getVectorLength()
Gets the length of the vectors (arrays) that will be used by the Rule. The length must be the same for all cells.

Returns:
The length of the vector stored by each cell.

doubleVectorRule

public abstract double[] doubleVectorRule(double[] cellArray,
                                          double[][] neighborArrays,
                                          int generation)
The rule for the cellular automaton which will be a function of the cell and its neighbors. The cell and its neighbors are double arrays.
By convention the neighbors' geometry should be indexed clockwise starting to the northwest of the cell.

Parameters:
cellArray - The current value of the cell being updated. The value is a double array.
neighborArrays - The current values of each neighbor. The values are double arrays. In other words, the first index is the number of the neighbor, and the second index is the array position for the that neighbor's array. By convention the neighbors' geometry should be indexed clockwise starting to the northwest of the cell.
generation - The current generation of the CA.
Returns:
A new state for the cell. Each element of the array must be between the values provided by getMinimumPermissibleValue() and getMaximumPermissibleValue().
